message: Here is a link to pictures of the 2011 season: http://gallery.me.com/daddyflo/100019
Nice. So does making syrup require much discussion' ?
@jvmed2 Yea, like..".Hey, where's the boiling sodas?" or "how'r they dripping?"
Boiling sodas=beer :) Trees stopped dripping today...too warm.  Watch the weather.  We need freezing nights for the trees to make sap.

Jonathan, Jones rule of 86 apply. It takes approximately 40 gallons of sap to make one gallon of syrup. The amount of sap exactly required to make one gallon of syrup is related to the sweetness. The sweeter the sap the less it takes to make one gallon of maple syrup. Jones rule of 86 says that: If you divide the sap sweetness into 86 you get the exact number of gallons to make 1 gallon of syrup. Thus, it will take 86 gallons of sap with 1% sweetness to make a gallon of syrup and only 17 gallons of sap at 5% sweetness. Our sap today was 2.1% so it would produce about 2.2 gallons. Maybe more than you wanted to know? Here's more: http://maple.dnr.cornell.edu/FAQ.htm
Harvested 90 gallons of sap today. Jonathan Freed asked: How much syrup does 90 gals. yield?

60 gallons of sap collected Saturday from partially frozen bags. The sap is what we called "freeze concentrated" and was 3% sugar. As an exercise figure out how much less we have to boil because the sap is 3% sugar instead of 2%. Use above "Rule of 86".
You should get another 2.1 gallons from only 60 gallons, as opposed to the 90 gallons it took the first time.
Correct. We will also expend less time and energy (wood + sweat). It's nice when Mother Nature helps.
Woot! Does that mean I get some maple beer when you brew it?

I was trying to get Kevin's roommate to brew some, but he decided not to.  I told him we'd provide him with all the sap he needed. :(  We could make some mead, but I think that takes quite a bit of syrup.
